Hi Sarah,

I wanted to recap the main points from our latest discussion on therapy methods, in case it’s helpful as you prepare your materials:

1. Integrating Mindful Acceptance Approach (MAA) with Integrated Behavioral Framework (IBF)
   • Mindfulness components (breath work, emotion-labeling, non-judgmental observation) cultivate self-awareness and distress tolerance.
   • IBF offers a clear, step-by-step behavioral change structure (goal-setting, stimulus control, reinforcement scheduling) that grounds the mindfulness work in actionable tasks.
   • Together, the two models appear to address both experiential avoidance and skill-deficit pathways, making them adaptable across diagnoses.

2. Empirical and clinical rationale
   • Growing evidence that mindfulness loosens rigid cognitive styles, thereby enhancing receptivity to behavioral interventions.
   • Early pilot data (small N = 12) indicated reduced GAD-7 and PHQ-9 scores after 6 weeks when MAA exercises preceded IBF homework.
   • Clients reported higher engagement scores (CSQ-8) when the weekly plan wove in brief mindfulness practices before exposure or behavioral activation assignments.

3. Practical application in our setting
   • Session template: 10-min grounding → 25-min behavioral work → 5-min values reflection/homework setup.
   • Homework menu uses the IBF hierarchy, but homework starts with a 3-min mindfulness check-in to consolidate learning.
   • We can pilot this in the Tuesday evening anxiety group beginning next month; outcome metrics will include GAD-7, SUDS ladder, and qualitative feedback.

4. Next steps
   • Draft a one-page client handout explaining the MAA+IBF flow.
   • Train facilitators on the mindfulness cue cards and the new behavioral tracking sheet.
   • Collect baseline measures from the upcoming cohort and set a mid-August review meeting to examine preliminary data.

Let me know if I missed anything or if you’d like additional detail on the pilot protocol. Happy to jump on a call later this week.

Best,
[Your Name]
